[BZ#746616] Display complete paths in file/folder selection

note.body:
#245 was closed as a duplicate of this ticket, with the explanation:

>  In the places where we display these, we mostly can't display full paths, because we're using GTK+ selectors that don't allow that. In some places, we have the "[parent] child" format. In those places, you're not actually seeing the immediate parent, but the first different parent. Showing the full path is generally not practical because we can't reliably fit the detail into the available space.

My view on that is:

* If GTK+ selectors prevent display of full paths, they can be replaced or additional components can be added to that provide full path information
* If a full path cannot reliably be shown in limited space, fit as much as possible with truncation, and provide the rest on hover

events.target_title: mouse: Add support for enabling and disabling mouse acceleration.

note.body:
Thank you all for your responses.

The primary use case for disabling mouse acceleration (at least from my experience), is that of those who wish to use their system for gaming, whereby the acceleration interferes with accuracy. I would suspect for these users disabling normalization would be desired anyway, as many of the users who care about such a thing, will already have a mouse with customizable DPI settings, as long as it was at least somewhat clear what was going on. I think there needs to be some method for this option, as for many less technical users who may switch from other operating systems (such as windows), the mouse acceleration present may be mystifying. Doing a quick search for disable mouse acceleration on google shows a huge number of results, and I think that for something that goes beyond simply preference for many users, it would make sense to expose in Gnome Settings. 

I do think that there is likely a better option for exposing the option though, perhaps calling it DPI Enhancement with a description as an OS like windows does, although this would likely be confusing to an end user. Would there be a term to use in this case that would be better? Or are there changes that would need to be made in Libinput before even exposing this? I do think that doing as other DE's do and simply exposing the profiles would be even more confusing.

events.target_title: Why is an alpha layer mask value always gamma corrected for 8 bit images with linear light?
Why is an alpha layer mask value always gamma corrected for 8 bit images with linear light?

note.body:
Thanks for the quick reply,

Yes i create a layer mask by transferring the alpha channel. I will try to add details to the reproduction steps:

Reproduction steps:

In Gimp 2.8.16:

1. create an image

2. add an alpha channel

3. add a layer mask 

4. select Transfer Layer's alpha channel then click on Add

5. click on the layer mask to select it

6. fill (with the bucket fill tool) the alpha mask with RGB(100, 100, 100) (with R, G and B in the range 0..255)

7. apply the mask

8. Result: RGBA(x,x,x,100) when applying the mask

see: ![Gimp_2_8_16_alpha](/uploads/9acd10a49ff3370a04305929999aac36/Gimp_2_8_16_alpha.png)


In Gimp 2.10.6:

1. create an "Precision:8bit" "Gamma:Linear light" image
do steps 2 to 7 as described in the gimp 2.8.16 usecase
8. Result: RGBA(x,x,x,34) when applying the mask

see ![Gimp_2_10_6_alpha](/uploads/cbc87edee25464e6593f534fb06d1756/Gimp_2_10_6_alpha.png)


Regards

This is not related to ZFS but to the location of the home directory for the users using the big ZFS disks. Snapd does not support home directories that are not in /home/*, symlinks are not sufficient. If you want to use snaps I can suggest that as a workaround, those users home directories be mounted or bind-mounted in /home/* .

events.target_title: Crash on startup (due to broken locale)

note.body:
In my opinion 44d7766a should be reverted and implemented in a more portable way. There shouldn't be UTF-8 strings in the C code and a po file used instead. Pan is intended to also work outside of gnome (see http://pan.rebelbase.com/faq/#General1 ). Also 44d7766a is incomplete if makes the program crash when it didn't crash before. 

There seems to be two generated files, en@boldquot.header and en@quot.header that supposed to do what 44d7766a is doing:

```bash
 # This catalog translates grave accent (0x60) and apostrophe (0x27) to
 # left single quotation mark (U+2018) and right single quotation mark (U+2019).
 # It also translates pairs of apostrophe (0x27) to
 # left single quotation mark (U+2018) and right single quotation mark (U+2019)
 # and pairs of quotation mark (0x22) to
 # left double quotation mark (U+201C) and right double quotation mark (U+201D).
```

events.target_title: Replace totally unnecessary UTF-8 colons by real ones.

note.body: I add my comments to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pan/issues/1 but I agree with @piotrdrag that this shouldn't be merged either.

events.target_title: Crash on startup (due to broken locale)

note.body: Another thing, 44d7766a broke most of the translations! The commit didn't update the msgid in the po files for other languages so it really should be reverted as it is very broken really.

events.target_title: Crash on startup (due to broken locale)

note.body:
Well, the problem here is that PAN is crashing because it doesn't either: a) detect that the user is not using a locale supporting UTF-8 and that g_locale_from_utf8() is failing and exiting with an error instead of segfault'ing; or b) using plain ASCII translatable strings and using gettext to use UTF-8 as recommended here https://developer.gnome.org/hig/stable/typography.html .

b) is a better solution because it will allow the program to run on non-UTF-8 locales, will not break most of the existing translations, and will still allow to use UTF-8 punctuation when supported.

events.target_title: Replace totally unnecessary UTF-8 colons by real ones.

note.body: My opinion is that this is a partial revert of commit 44d7766a , and as that commit is causing the crash it should be reverted completely instead and implemented in a more portable way. Otherwise that app could still crash if the user access other messages with the wrong locale.

note.body:
>  That's pretty much what the scanner calibration in the settings is. I assume you did calibrate your scanner?

Well, this is embarassing. I did not even notice that option, and yes, that is exactly what i was looking for. Thanks for the help!

> Based on my experience, with scanners with both ADF and Flatbed, you can safely use the same calibration settings for both

With paperwork, i am actually only using the ADF, so i just calibrated using the ADF and now it works fine. :thumbsup:

events.target_title: Box hide the whole page

note.body: Could you confirm that these boxes have their upper-left coordinates set to `(0, 0)`? To do so, just look into the `paper.X.words` file where `X` is the page number. For a test run, you could remove all those `...` where the `title` attribute contains `bbox 0 0 ` and see if the large blocking boxes are still displayed. If this fixes the issue, filtering out those boxes is trivial, as I did in !781, which has not made it to any new release though.

events.target_title: Gnome-shell core dump every 5 minutes

note.body:
I ran:
```bash
sudo dnf debuginfo-install -y mozjs60 gjs glib2 mutter gnome-shell
```
It installed the packages without error. Then, not more than two minutes later, it crashed again. Is there a **Gnome** program I need to run to report? I've been using **Logs**.

events.target_title: Use lazy loading instead of initial sync for rooms and messages

note.body:
If you're using incremental syncs correctly, you will not lose track of any rooms (unless the homeserver malfunctions). When you pass `since` to `/sync`, you are guaranteed to receive all state, room membership, and so forth that changed since the sync response that you got the parameter you're passing to `since` from. Calling joined_rooms should not be necessary.

Note that for this to work, the state cache must use some form of transactional storage, such that a the current state will always be stored alongside the `next_batch` parameter from the sync most recently applied to the state. If these diverge, the cache will become corrupted.

events.target_title: Resizing left or top side of GNOME Terminal window on Wayland causes opposite sides move

note.body:
@bugaevc I can confirm that when resizing a GNOME Terminal window it follows discrete grid steps (snapping to invisible grid)

**BUT** those discrete steps are done as you are dragging the side or corner, meaning you can only disengage the mouse at one of the allowed grid locations and it shouldn't ever move the opposite window sides (which should have already been at one of the allowed grid locations)

When I resize the right or bottom sides or bottom-right corner it follows discrete grid steps and wherever I disengage the mouse the opposite left and top sides **do not move** their location.

When I resize the left or top sides, or bottom-left, top-left, and top-right corners it follows discrete grid steps but wherever I disengage the mouse the opposite right and bottom sides move from their location.  Something is not right with the logic controlling how the window is resized.

You should be able to easily reproduce this yourself and you will see the undesired behavior.

There does appear to be a rending problem with texts, I got it down to a small svg.  If there is a path before the text not wrapped in a g, it causes the text to go wonky. see attached broken.svg.   Once you wrap the path in a 
 `<g>`  all appears better (not sure if this is always the case).

PNG:
![broken](/uploads/c22e572e6274ed1c05032861ac396f0e/broken.png)

SVG:
![broken.svg](/uploads/e806a47d94fe4b548be9a5025ac20466/broken.svg)

Here is the same svg with the path wrapped in a `<g>`. The text renders correctly again.  (doesn't seem to matter if the `<text>` is wrapped in g).

PNG:
![wrapped](/uploads/757b7b72dce967aa2f6d230706a35586/wrapped.png)

SVG:
![wrapped.svg](/uploads/4a4e80552607e001c5f47e31ba3f78c2/wrapped.svg)

bad:
`<svg><path><text></svg>`

also bad:
`<svg><g><path><text></g></svg>`

good:
`<svg><g><path></g><text></svg>`

The font I'm using is in my fontpath when running rsvg-convert.
I'm running librsvg-2.44.6 on centos7 (build from source).

Cameron

events.target_title: Searching as not effect on the map

note.body:
TLDR: add an icon file to your theme with the name mark-location.svg

Discovered a quick hack. The problem is the line:
```
Gjs-Message: 13:19:34.801: JS LOG: DEBUG: Failed to load image: Icon 'mark-location' not present in theme ubuntu-mono-dark
```

I tried changing themes to generic gnome and same result. So I hunted for a theme with the icon, it turns out theme icons are stored in /usr/shar/icon.

```
find /usr/share/icons/ -name 'mark-location*'
/usr/share/icons/Adwaita/scalable/actions/mark-location-symbolic.svg
/usr/share/icons/HighContrast/32x32/actions/mark-location.png
/usr/share/icons/HighContrast/22x22/actions/mark-location.png
/usr/share/icons/HighContrast/48x48/actions/mark-location.png
/usr/share/icons/HighContrast/256x256/actions/mark-location.png
/usr/share/icons/HighContrast/24x24/actions/mark-location.png
/usr/share/icons/HighContrast/16x16/actions/mark-location.png
/usr/share/icons/gnome/scalable/actions/mark-location-symbolic.svg
```

I decided to try a quick hack since I was using the gnome theme:
```
sudo cp /usr/share/icons/gnome/scalable/actions/mark-location-symbolic.svg /usr/share/icons/gnome/scalable/actions/mark-location.svg
```

That didnt work, then I stumbled onto https://superuser.com/questions/711029/how-do-i-add-icons-to-the-hicolor-icon-theme-manually which indicated that I needed to simply update the cache
```
sudo gtk-update-icon-cache -f /usr/share/icons/gnome
```



There are several bugs here and being a gnome newbie I do not know how to report these:
* default gnome themes are not shipping with mark-location icons
* gnome-maps fails on a missing icon. 
* gnome-maps should provide a default set of icons if there isnt any in the theme.


gnome-maps should still function when resources not critical to the operation are missing. If those resources are critical then gnome-maps should provide a default/fallback.

note.body:
Oh, actually, I've just registered to report the same issue.

But I've got a bit deeper. I wrote a small Python script that generates one-line files to test gedit:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import sys


if __name__ == '__main__':
    if len(sys.argv) != 2:
        print('usage: %s LEN' % sys.argv[0])
        sys.exit(1)
    n = int(sys.argv[1])
    print('0' * n, file=open('test%d.txt' % n, 'w'))

```

And then I tested gedit with files of different line length. The test showed that gedit crashes with >4076-bytes line.
I can reproduce that with version 3.30.2 from Fedora 29 and with master branch from github.

events.target_title: Add preview functionality for 3D model formats (e.g. .obj)

note.body:
Sorry, I just realised I never replied to this.

The app I'd most associate with these models is Blender, but as with images there are a bunch of programs that can handle them (Wings3D and Misfit Model 3D come to mind).

I think preview functionality would actually need to be implemented in Sushi, as unlike images I don't know of anywhere lower in the stack that would have the functionality to load and preview 3D models. 

Loading and displaying .OBJ and .STL and rendering with OpenGL is pretty straightforward, and in fact there are libraries like assimp (https://github.com/assimp/assimp) which would give you support for 40+ 3D formats out of the box if you used it.

My recommendation would be that if the user is trying to preview a 3D model, use assimp to import it into a consistent structure and then render a preview to a GtkGLArea.

note.body:
@aklapper **As far as I know**, choosing a dark/light theme designed **only** for GTK+ applications and **doesn't** support qt-based applications like `arc-theme`, **doesn't** effect the qt-based applications look. 

For example when I set the `arc-dark` theme for the Applications Theme field in Tweaks, apps like `qbittorrent` still were showing up in their **default light theme!**

events.target_title: Connection failed - timeout

note.body: Hi, I made a little research and found that leaving out nm-fortisslvpn-pppd-plugin.so in nm-fortisslvpn-service will make the connection to get established. It subsequently fails because there is no way for NetworkManager to communicate with the pppd and the former assumes the latter is dead (this is plain guessing on my side). In addition, nm-fortisslvpn-service sets options --no-routes and --no-dns which then need config options to supply DNS and routes. Why should these be forced? Shouldn't it be better to leave those options to the config file, if needed?

events.target_title: Connection failed - timeout

note.body: It is not, but I need that the routes provided by the server be honored, so that setting breaks my setup. And, as you say, you can always config them away.

events.target_title: Connection failed - timeout

note.body: But more to the point, in the tests I made, apparently the call to nm_phasechange is what blocks the connection -- NOT CORRECT, see below

events.target_title: Connection failed - timeout

note.body:
Here are further experimental results. 
(1) If I make nm-fortisslvpn-service have openfortivpn load nm-fortisslvpn-pppd-plugin.so, nm_ip_up() never gets called from pppd's ipcp_up(), as if there were no ip-up event. I tried loading an empty plugin (with no notifiers) and changing notifiers by pppd hooks (not possible for exitnotify), and this behavior is consistently observed (nm_phasechange() gets called, though, up to "establish").
(2) However, if I leave out the plugin (do not set the option --pppd-plugin for openfortivpn in nm-fortisslvpn-service), pppd establishes the connection and sets ip addreses, dnss and routes (depending on the options passed to openfortivpn) as expected. This is done in ipcp_up().
(3) In either case, I get a "Looks like pppd didn't initialize our dbus module" message after 10 seconds. 
(4) If I increase NM_FORTISSLVPN_WAIT_PPPD to 100 sec then pppd gets killed in one minute by journal[11536]: Connect timer expired, disconnecting.

events.target_title: Connection failed - timeout

note.body:
Hi there. 
I found that NetworkManager-fortisslvpn connects beautifully if I include the option --pppd-log <file> in the openfortivpn command line (in nm-fortisslvpn-service) so that pppd debug is up and pppd logs to <file> in addition to syslog. I can set <file> to /dev/null not to have log files lying around. There's some type of incompatibility between systemd-journald.service logging from pppd and from NetworkManager. Any ideas on that side?
Thanks

events.target_title: Connection failed - timeout

note.body:
And, if I include option

logfile filename

in /etc/ppp/options, then, NetworkManager-fortisslvpn connects beautifully without any need to modify its code. If I remove the logfile option, it times out.

I am more than puzzled by this because the logging routine in pppd is as simple as it can be and I can't see what strange interaction there may be.

note.body: Hate to wake an old thread like this, but is there any plans to add custom formats to the top bar clock?

events.target_title: Custom format of date in top panel

note.body:
Well, yeah, the options are (tweaks)"Show seconds", (tweaks)"Show date" and (regular settings)12h/24h. It may be based on locale, but it does not respect its formats. I have even manually changed my locale file to try to get a format that I want. The basic display is for example "thu 12:42". I can add the date and seconds through tweaks to make it "thu nov 22, 12:42:50". I'm guessing that the locale provides the abbreviated names, but the formats specified in LC_TIME are not respected. I would for example like the clock to say "2018-11-22, 12:42:50". 

The best thing would probably be to have an option to respect the `d_t_fmt` format for date and time from the current locale. After all it is a bit confusing that the Settings -> Region & Language -> Formats -> Preview looks like this:
![image](/uploads/6ede26f5a27df07ea7d2f220cf03aa4d/image.png)

But the clock (and calendar) looks like this:
![image](/uploads/97c2cf5909723df4945540c63d95ede9/image.png)

Or with tweaks, like this:

![image](/uploads/a73235cec060b50e99d696a2b14a589d/image.png)

Which looks nothing like the locale formats.

So maybe not custom formats (would be cool though to be able to use the [STRFTIME(3)](http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/strftime.3.html) format to specify how the clock should look), but rather a respect locale format option?

events.target_title: Custom format of date in top panel

note.body:
There are of course a couple of extensions that do this well, for example: [Clock Override](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/1206/clock-override/) and [Datetime Format](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/1173/datetime-format/)

But since I have multiple displays and use [an extension](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/921/multi-monitors-add-on/) to show the top bar on all my displays (this would also be nice to have built into gnome), the format extensions mentioned above only change the clock on the main monitor, since the duplicated top bars gets the clock from gnome and not the extensions. I have tried to get [the maintainers of these extension to work together](https://github.com/spin83/multi-monitors-add-on/issues/68), but dependencies between gnome extensions are apparently very unreliable.

As such, I turn to gnome, to get clock formatting implemented on a lower level so I can format the clock on all my monitors. And maybe even get multi monitor support for the top bar in gnome as well.

I hope that multiple monitors is a good enough use case to get this implemented. It is pretty common to use a gnome distro and have multiple monitors after all. (most developers at any company using a gnome distro)

events.target_title: AnyRGB for Colors/Desaturate/Desaturate to luma/luminance

note.body:
@ellestone 
>  What sort of thing is this `"input"` ? Is it always available everywhere?

Yes, if I am correct, [GEGL nodes have "input pads" and "output pads"](http://gegl.org/operation-api.html ) that can be used for connecting to GEGL nodes in an application like GIMP. That is why [in gegl-operation.c, most functions](https://github.com/GNOME/gegl/blob/master/gegl/operation/gegl-operation.c) are defined with two arguments e.g. like this:
```
gegl_operation_get_source_format (GeglOperation *operation,
                                  const gchar *padname) {...}
```
Where the second argument (here: padname) is of type gchar (i.e. char, similar to a text-string). this second argument seems to be a flag which internally gets assigned either the value "input" or "output". It is passed to downstream functions in GEGL which e.g. check if this pad name is == "input" or != NULL and thereby decide how to proceed.

events.target_title: Preferences option to convert to Preferred RGB profile doesn't work

note.body:
Can that option be removed completely? If the opened image has a "fancy" profile, there will be a good reason and sRGB would probably not be the best choice for editing. Providing 2 ways for getting the same goal results in confusion and clutters the GUI. Just clearly document that the workflow is (steps in brackets can usually be skipped for users that don't know about color managementand or edit images from the internet): 
1. Open an image (images without color profile information are treated as being encoded in sRGB color space with sRBG TRC). 
2. Select "Image -> Precision -> 16u or 32f" (can be done by default: Users that have no time for waiting will have enough RAM these days) [and set channel encoding],
3. [If desired, do Image -> Color Management -> Convert to color profile...] 
4. Edit the image. 
5. [Convert to profile for export, see step 3. sRGB (sRGB TRC) is a good choice for the internet].
6. Change precision for export to bit depth 8u or 16u. 
7. Upon export, choose whether the current profile should be embedded or not.

events.target_title: Docs need an update: new color management features

note.body:
Confusingly, export dialogs have no options for selecting channel bit-depth and the embedded color profile. So I suggest to add a short overview to the beginning of [the manual Part II, Chapter 5](https://docs.gimp.org/2.10/en/become-a-gimp-wizard.html) and make it the new "Chapter 5.1. Recommended workflow"
>>>  
The following gives an overview over the recommended workflow with GIMP. For details, see [Chapter 11. Color Management with GIMP](https://docs.gimp.org/2.10/en/gimp-imaging-color-management.html) 
1. Open an image.
1. Select `Image -> Precision -> 16 bit unsigned integer` or `32 bit floating point` (slowest, editing operations cause less color artefacts). For most operations you can keep the channel encoding set to `Perceptual gamma (sRGB)`. [Most operations will be automatically calculated in linear light with 32 bit floating point precision internally anyway](https://docs.gimp.org/2.10/de/gimp-image-precision.html).
1. If desired, do `Image -> Color Management -> Convert to color profile...`. Gimp 2.10.12 may have issues if the profile for editing is not `Gimp built-in sRGB`.
1. Edit the image
1. Save the project in .xcf format: `File -> Save as`. 
1. Convert to profile for export (see step 3). `Gimp built-in sRGB` is a good choice for high compatibility with non-color managed software.
1. Change precision for export via `Image -> Precision`. For compatibility with other software, channel encoding `Perceptual gamma (sRGB)` and `8 bit unsigned integer` (high compatibility) or `16 bit unsigned integer` precision is a good choice)
1. Export: `File  -> Export as ...`. For high quality images, choose TIFF (.tif) or PNG (.png) and select `Save color profile`.
1. If you changed precision or profile for export, undo (`Edit -> Undo`) steps 6 and/or 7 before you eventually continue editing. 
>>>

events.target_title: "Join all monitors" option in the display switcher results in a blank desktop. This display switcher needs to be LESS accessible.

note.body:
On a Acer SF315-41G laptop, when in Gnome 3 (Wayland), I now can't get mirror or join screens (both screens won't become active at same time (built-in and external). Interesting the display dialog knows one of the screens is inactive, but 1) there is no dialog control AFAIK to make it active, probably because join/mirror was actually supposed to do that.
2)  the Laptop has its fun Super-P thingo, which mostly annoys me. It used to work, and it still brings up the display swapper  but since an update or 2 ago, it hasn't given the desired result.
3) When selecting join displays from the dialog, both screens go black, and then the builtin in will flash on then off, give up and go black, and the settings back to the external monitor only. It then has the nerve to ask if I want to save or revert, even though the setting change has failed. Or only the built-in stays on, but it isn't the primary screen, and no menus or dialog, and I'm forced to super-P again.

It used to work on Gnome 3 wayland on this laptop.

I think its a conspiracy to ensure gnome 3 / wayland doesn't have to deal with 2 screens at same time.
So I either make do with only the bigger external monitor, or I tend to use the current alternate X11 desktops (Gnome classic, Gnome on Xorg, LXDE) that seem to be still usable, and don't currently have this arrgh... no screens two at once problem.

A command line tool that can deal with some of these independent options might help.
I dfid write lua script to configure via xrandr, to get what I wanted. Seems to be impossible to do this for wayland, even though there are only 4 options to choose from using the Fn-F5 (super-P) on this laptop. Is their some sort of libwayland subsystem that a C program could call? How buried in code-bloat are these things today?  Is their an API?

events.target_title: Infinite loop when calculating deep counts of directories

note.body:
I remember experiencing this behaviour for as long as I can remember, I think at least a decade. I haven't noticed a determining factor causing it, but it happens with normal folders too. If I currently select all my personal data files (folders containing the files) and click "Properties", I experience the loop, but if I move one level up, and select the whole partition (the partition icon (I have my personal data files on a separate partition, but not an a separate hard drive)), the loop doesn't happen. If I divide the folders inside the partition in different subgroups, the loop either happens or doesn't happen. Size of the selection isn't the determining factor. I can make a large size selection with only a few folders, and get normal behaviour, and make a smaller selection and get the loop. I can also include any of the folders in a subgroup that doesn't go to loop.  

During experiencing this problem I have used numerous distributions, almost all Ubuntu based, with Gnome desktop. Currently I'm using Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS. I have never tested the behaviour systematically before, so I don't know if it has always been exactly the same as I describe above.

note.body:
This patch still applies, and it works wonderfully!

If we want to look for more design guidance, this feature is also in [Skim](https://skim-app.sourceforge.io/index.html), so we can look at how they've implemented it. When can we get this mainlined? Tomorrow I'm going to try and package evince for all of my labmate's machines with this patch applied :)

As far as my experience: for my usecase it's absolutely imperative that we have previews like this patch does, rather than whole page thumbnails, since I'm using it to look up citation numbers in the bibliography. I'm currently using it with `link_dest_doc.y = ev_link_dest_get_top (dest, NULL) - 5` and `view->link_preview.left = link_dest_view.x - 10;` --- perhaps we should see what Skim does here.

events.target_title: WKD (Web Key Directory) support for OpenPGP

note.body:
I guess I probably should have commented here instead of bugzilla...

As Milan pointed out in bugzilla, Camel invokes gpg and passes it the email addresses and not a key fingerprint or identity, so technically Web Key lookups should Just Work(tm).

That said, the gpg invocation could potentially be slower because gpg will have to call out to the network to look up all the keys since none of them will have been pre-fetched as the user was composing his/her message.

Of course, that's only a problem if the Evolution user has never emailed those people before... how often will that happen? In theory it could happen a lot, in practice, probably not often.


This is what I would suggest to anyone interested in implementing *improved* support for this in Evolution (i.e. making it work like kmail) and/or just moving toward GPGME (which I would advise as a good idea long-term):

1. No need to move Camel toward GPGME initially. Someone could simply add logic to Evolution's Message Composer window to use GPGME to do background key lookups so that they are pre-fetched by the time Camel invokes gpg.

2. Then migrate Camel to GPGME.


For anyone interested in (2), just clone GMime's GMimeCryptoContext stuff. I've already done the work there to support GPGME and Camel and GMime both used the same design for the CryptoContext stuff when I originally wrote them back in the early 2000's.

GMime's has evolved a bit since then in order to provide more info, but is effectively the same.

There's 2 main source files to look at in GMime for GPGME support:

https://github.com/jstedfast/gmime/blob/master/gmime/gmime-gpgme-utils.c
https://github.com/jstedfast/gmime/blob/master/gmime/gmime-gpg-context.c

events.target_title: Fails to parse base64-encoded message/rfc822 attachment

note.body:
FWIW, GMail has problems with these as well, based on my experience with their IMAP responses for these types of messages.

GMail (and potentially other IMAP servers) will send `body-part-basic` expressions instead of `body-part-msg` expressions when they encounter `message/rfc822` MIME parts that are illegally encoded using base64 (or quoted-printable?). According to rfc3501, IMAP servers are REQUIRED to send `body-part-msg` expressions for `message/rfc822` parts, however, it is understandable why GMail (and other IMAP servers?) do what they do in this particular case because they clearly handle this error in the same fashion that I opted to handle it in GMime - which is to treat encoded message/rfc822 body parts as opaque leaf-node (aka 'basic') body parts.

For an example of GMail's IMAP response, see https://github.com/jstedfast/MailKit/issues/32#issuecomment-39682556

events.target_title: Fails to parse base64-encoded message/rfc822 attachment

note.body:
Sure! https://github.com/jstedfast/gmime/commit/a7d6af5d69d0f5106fc8c0fe2a7218d294909870

GMime has a way to register which subclass to instantiate for a given mime-type which is what `object = g_mime_object_new_type (options, type, subtype);` is all about. The `type` and `subtype` strings are only used for creating the correct type of GMimeObject (or CamelObject in Camel), the `application/octet-stream` value isn't actually set on the instantiated GMimePart (in case that's not clear looking at the patch).

The important part of the patch is that you'll need to check the `Content-Type` header value is `message/rfc822` (or similar `message/*` types as seen in the patch) and whether or not it has a `Content-Transfer-Encoding` that is set to `base64` or `quoted-printable` - if so, create a GMimePart and have the parser continue parsing as if it is parsing any other `application/octet-stream` part.

Hope that helps.

```

night-light does not affect cursor color
night-light does not affect cursor color

note.body:
I remember having the same issue on Windows with flux. There, I solved it by using "software cursor rendering" - a Windows registry "hack" described [here](https://photo.stackexchange.com/questions/3436/how-to-apply-color-management-to-the-windows-7-mouse-cursor).

Now, flux can force software cursor by itself as described in their [faq](https://justgetflux.com/faq.html), however, it's closed source so I don't know how.

I googled around if there is an option to force software cursors in Linux. Xorg seems to implement the feature - [post on reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/linuxquestions/comments/21h663/question_can_i_set_my_cursor_to_be_a_software/). I can't try it as I use Wayland with my GNOME.

Anyway, that's just where I got if somebody wanted to follow-up on this issue...

note.body:
Finally found this file on the system:

`-rwxr-xr-x. 1 root root 11096 Aug  7  2013 /usr/lib64/babl-0.1/sse-fixups.so`

from 2013 that was not owned by any installed package. Evidently this is left over from some much earlier GIMP installation.

`sse-fixups.so-NOPT`

This *may* be the solution, though I'm concerned about what else may be left from prior installations of GIMP that could cause problems. (This system has been around a long time.) I'm content to close this issue if that seems appropriate to you folks. Thanks a bunch; sorry about the wild goose chase.

events.target_title: New unlock/login design

note.body:
I think I have noticed an important new point regarding the complaints about typing the password straight away. 

> showing _something_ before the authentication prompt is necessary on mobile devices to prevent accidental interactions

Desktop users (me included) complain that they see this _something_ before seeing the password input field. So this something is put there to prevent accidental interactions. However the accidental interactions are already possible because of another feature: technically one can start typing the password before seeing the password prompt. 

But is it really *this* important to prevent accidental interactions with the password field? In this particular scenario of providing the password to unlock the device are such interactions really harmful? Is this harm bad enough to warrant breaking an ages old UI paradigm "you can type when you see a text cursor"? And can this harm be alleviated?

So we have to choose one of the following:

1) The consequences of accidental interactions with password input
2) The necessity to either

    a) do an extra step (swipe, spacebar, esc) to see the password input or 

    b) to learn yet another special case to type highly confidential password while not seeing the text cursor

Please weigh these options against each other. I hope that you decide in favor of showing the focused password input straight away. I am sure this will resolve most if not all complaints.

events.target_title: GLib-based programs started printing GLib-DEBUG: posix_spawn avoided (fd close requested)
GLib-based programs started printing GLib-DEBUG: posix_spawn avoided (fd close requested)

note.body:
I avoided the wording ‘bug in GLib’ exactly to avoid such discussion of semantics because this is not a blame game.  This is about fixing a real-world problem.

Granted, the API documentation has never said GLib would never emit such messages (there are lots of things unsaid everyone takes for granted) -- but it is how it behaved for almost 20 years.  Now the behaviour has changed and various programs started spewing GLib debug messages.  Some may be modified soon to avoid it, some in three years, some never.  This is a disruption not proportional to the utility of the change.

events.target_title: GLib-based programs started printing GLib-DEBUG: posix_spawn avoided (fd close requested)

note.body:
Second, AFAICT filtering by message domain is not the correct behaviour.  Which of the following is false?

1. If a program wants to do something useful with the messages in an environment like MS Windows, it needs to install a log handler.

2. Messages from underlying libraries (GTK+, GLib, ...) are in such case similarly useful and should be handled similarly to messages produced by the program itself, so the handler should process all domains.

3. Production code does not print debug messages.  They can occur in time critical code paths and while a computation can run 20x slower when debugging, that would definitely be a problem in production code.  So they are normally compiled out.

events.target_title: Option to open Plain Text composer in Preformatted

note.body:
Thanks for the engagement @mcrha 

* Sorry that I forgot my environment info. I added it to the issue description.

* My concern is about the composer window. The preview panel correctly wraps plain-text emails that do not have hard line breaks.

* Preformatted paragraph mode has some problems, as you point out:

  * It is still an HTML email, but even worse because it forces the viewer to use preformatted text which removes their client's hint to wrap the lines.
  * When I hit the right side of the window, it scrolls the entire window instead of wrapping. That makes it difficult to edit an email.

* View->Visually Wrap Long Lines appears to be exactly what I want if it could be combined with an infinite line length in the preferences window. I wasn't aware of it before your suggestion and have been playing with it. It doesn't seem to work. I don't see any change in behavior whether it is set or not. The line length seems to be determined by the number of characters in Edit->Preferences->Composer Preferences->Number of characters for word wrapping. If that number is high, the window scrolls horizontally. If it is low, the line wraps with hard line breaks (not just visually). It doesn't update when I change the window width.

* Wrapping in the preview panel is great.

I updated the issue description to make this more clear.

Thank you @mcrha. I had not noticed that the text type drop-down continued to be active when "Plain Text" was selected. That is surprising, given that plain text is not actually formatted.

You are correct that with "Preformatted" selected and "Visually Wrap Long Lines" checked, the composer window behaves as I desire.

Should I create a new issue to be able to set "Preformatted" as the default "format" when composing plain text email?

note.body:
I should also say that I am impressed with the level of engagement I received in this issue tracker. This problem has driven me crazy since I migrated to Evolution a few months ago, and I am excited that you helped me find a work-around.

Thank you @mcrha !

"comment=x-gvfs-show" breaks mounting as user in 1.38.1-1.1
"comment=x-gvfs-show" breaks mounting as user in 1.38.1-1.1

note.body:
@oholy, my distribution is Manjaro, `ls /mnt/Data` lists the content normally, but when I tried to open this volume in Thunar, this error would pop up:

```
Mount is denied because the NTFS volume is already exclusively opened.
The volume may be already mounted, or another software may use it which
could be identified for example by the help of the 'fuser' command.
```

`fuser -m /dev/sda1` didn't produce any output. It seems Thunar tried to mount it and could not, because it was already mounted by root.

Anyway, I tried removing `comment=`. Yes, it is mounted without it. It's strange because I distinctly remember that when I was setting up mounting of this volume several years ago, `x-gvfs-show` by itself was a wrong option, it had to be in this exact form `comment=x-gvfs-show` to have effect. I don't remember exactly what the problem was, perhaps the same as the one that topic starter had here: https://askubuntu.com/questions/594197/unrecognized-mount-option-x-gvfs-show-or-missing-value. But I do remember that I needed `comment=`.

In any case now I updated gvfs again and everything seems to be working with option `x-gvfs-show`, without `comment=`.
